Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of pharyngeal cancer, admitted to the hospital with a desquamating rash following Ibuprofen use. He had a complicated hospital course with renal failure, hepatitis, and progression of rash to desquamation. The patient then developed worsening respiratory status and hypoxemic respiratory failure, leading to intubation. He was transferred to the ICU with hypoxemic respiratory failure and sepsis.

The patient is currently experiencing significant hypoxemic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. He has ongoing inspiratory effort and ventilator dys-synchrony. Oxygenation compromise may be related to effusions and multi-focal infiltrates. The plan includes moving to PCV at 30/10 with Ti=0.8, repeating ABG, pursuing ECHO to evaluate potential contribution from cardiogenic insult, and providing sedation and bronchodilators as needed.

The patient also has sepsis with a likely pulmonary source, persistent compromise, and requires continued support with pressors and CVP. Acute renal failure is suspected and will need to be supported with adequate urine output and creatinine monitoring. The patient is being treated for TEN with Prednisone and will consult dermatology for further input.

ICU care includes nutrition through tube feeds, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcers, and VAP. The patient's code status is full, and he is currently in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1) Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing significant hypoxemic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. Complications may include further deterioration in oxygenation and ventilation, increased secretions, and potential need for tracheostomy.
2) Sepsis: The patient has sepsis with a likely pulmonary source. Complications may include organ dysfunction, systemic inflammatory response, and potential septic shock.
3) Acute Renal Failure: The patient is suspected to have acute renal failure, likely due to ATN. Complications may include worsening renal function, electrolyte imbalances, and fluid overload.
4) TEN (Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis): The patient is being treated for TEN, which is a severe skin condition. Complications may include progression of skin involvement, secondary infections, and systemic involvement.
5) Pneumonia: The patient has multi-focal infiltrates and is being treated for pneumonia. Complications may include worsening lung function, respiratory distress, and potential need for bronchoscopy.
6) Cardiogenic Insult: The patient's ECHO will be done to evaluate potential contribution from cardiogenic insult. Complications may include heart failure and reduced cardiac output.
7) DVT/PE: The patient is at risk for developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) due to immobility and underlying comorbidities.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was improving until Saturday when his mental status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status and started on dopamine for hypotension. The patient was transferred to another hospital for management of respiratory failure and hypotension.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has likely acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or aspiration. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed normal left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), ruling out cardiogenic shock. The patient's smoking history puts him at risk for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The plan is to wean PEEP and repeat arterial blood gas (ABG).

2. Hypotension: The patient likely has sepsis from an underlying lung infection. He is currently on levophed and vasopressin. The plan is to continue to wean off pressors as tolerated, monitor urine output (UOP) and systolic blood pressures (SBPs), and follow up with cultures.

3. Acid/Base Disturbances: The patient has an anion gap metabolic acidosis (AG of 11) that is likely due to uremia (normal lactate levels, not diabetic).

   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and started on dopamine for hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   management of respiratory failure and hypotension.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Unclear etiology.  Given AMS, family report of
   poor difficulty swallowing, and acute change in CXR, aspiration is
   possible.  HAP and CHF/Volume overload also possible particularly given
   his hyperdynamic EF (reportedly 75%) and volume rescusciation given his
   desquamation.  Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.
   Vasculitis in lungs less likely given no blood seen on bronch, stable
   HCT.
   - AC with FI02 tonight, consider weaning tomorrow
   - possible bronch in the AM
   - Vanco/Zosyn for HAP
   - Sputum culture
   - ECHO in the AM
   - continue prednisone taper and nebs for ? COPD
   - repeat CXR in AM
   - repeat ABG in AM
   - check ANCA
   - may need chest CT if no clear etiology determined.
   .
   #) Hypotension: Could be related to intubation, sedation as occurred
   peri-intubation.  However, infection/sepsis is also a possibility given
   his clinical picture.  Also, patient recently diuresed so hypovolemia
   possibly contributing (though CVP not transducing).  Lactic acidosis
   considered, but lactate normal.
   -d/c dopamine as patient recently in afib with RVR
   -levophed to keep MAP >60
   -CVP not [**Location (un) 103**], Vigileo for fluid status
   -good UOP, got IVF tonight.
   -continue steroid taper
   -blood cultures, urine cultures, urine legionella antigen
   -hold metoprolol and hold lasix
   .
   #) Rash: Unclear etiology.  Leukoclastic vasculitis most commonly
   associated with medication effect but patient only noted to take 2
   advil.  No toxin exposures.  Could be paraneoplastic phenomenon given
   h/o throat cancer and recent weight loss, poor PO and dysphagia.
   -wound care consult (were using eucerin cream at OSH)
   -supportive care for now.
   -on prednisone taper
   -no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Renal Failure: Likely related to desquamation/rash and dehydration.
   Creatinine trending down and close to baseline (though up from 1.4 on
   Saturday).  Less likely to be pulmonary-renal syndrome given
   improvement in renal and worsening in pulm status
   -renally dose medications.
   -repeat creatinine in AM, if worsening would check urine lytes
   -u/a with culture
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Patient's MS initially improving and then
   declined with decline in respiratory status.  Patient at high risk for
   delerium given underlying dementia, and then received multiple doses of
   haldol, some ativan and ?ambien.  Less likely ETOH withdrawl given pt.
   drinks 2 beers/[**Last Name (un) **], but this is possible.
   -f/cu CT head from OSH
   -give thiamine.
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Likely [**12-21**] volume depletion during diuresis.
   -fluids tonight, recheck lytes in AM.
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) afib with RVR: patient in sinus here, holding metoprolol given
   hupotension.
   .
   #) hypothyroidism: Patient on 75mcg PO

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was intubated for worsening respiratory status and started on dopamine for hypotension. The patient's respiratory failure could be due to aspiration, hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), or congestive heart failure (CHF)/volume overload. The hypotension may be related to intubation, sedation, infection/sepsis, or hypovolemia. The rash could be caused by leukoclastic vasculitis, medication effect, or a paraneoplastic phenomenon. Renal failure is likely related to dehydration and desquamation. The altered mental status may be due to delirium, ethanol withdrawal, or medication side effects.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure could be due to aspiration, HAP, or CHF/volume overload. Possible interventions include AC with FiO2, bronchoscopy, and chest CT.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be related to intubation, sedation, infection/sepsis, or hypovolemia. Possible interventions include discontinuing dopamine, levophed to maintain MAP >60, and Vigileo for fluid status.
3. Rash: The rash could be caused by leukoclastic vasculitis, medication effect, or a paraneoplastic

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with initial admission for rash and now presenting with hypoxemic respiratory failure complicated by sepsis. The initial insult for respiratory failure may be aspiration event in the setting of delirium, hospital-acquired pneumonia, or alternative source of sepsis. The patient has been able to maintain improvement in oxygenation and stability of pressor requirements over the past 24 hours. However, there are concerns regarding the evolution of renal failure and persistent gap and non-gap acidosis with decreased pH.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure/ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (ARDS): The patient is experiencing hypoxemia despite being on PEEP=18 and FIO2=0.5. Decreasing PEEP to 14 and maintaining the same driving pressure has resulted in an increase in Vt to 480 from 450cc, suggesting modest overdistention at previous PEEP. Further evaluation of ABG is needed.

2. Pneumonia: The patient has significant pulmonary infiltrate and likely hospital-acquired pneumonia. Broad coverage antibiotics (Vanco, Cefepime, Ceftriaxone, Cipro, Flagyl) will be continued.

3. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: This is present but quite mild. Improved PEEP titration may help decrease CO2 levels at the next ABG.

4. Sepsis: The patient will continue on

The patient is on multiple antibiotics for suspected pneumonia and has shown some improvement in his condition. He is receiving respiratory support through an endotracheal tube and mechanical ventilation. The patient's vital signs are relatively stable, but he does have impaired skin integrity, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and atrial fibrillation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's severe respiratory compromise may lead to further deterioration and difficulty in weaning off mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: Despite receiving appropriate antibiotics, the patient's sepsis may worsen if the source of infection is not adequately controlled.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's worsening renal function may progress to end-stage renal disease, requiring dialysis or renal transplant.
4. ARDS: The patient's ARDS may not improve, leading to prolonged respiratory support and increased risk of complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
5. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity increases the risk of pressure ulcers, infections, and other skin-related complications.
6. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's acute atrial fibrillation may persist or recur, leading to potential hemodynamic instability and thromboembolic events.

   Assessment and Plan
   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and started on dopamine for hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   management of respiratory failure and hypotension.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Likely in ARDS [**12-21**] underlying HAP or
   aspiration.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o CHF. Patient's smoking history
   puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis in lungs less likely given no
   blood seen on bronch, stable HCT. sputum cx grew GBS. ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   CXR indicates cavitation -> will oprder CT chest  for better eval. CT
   showed LLL pneumonia.
   - on PC, will decr PEEP and repeat ABG
   - continue Vanco/Cefepime/Cipro for HAP for now
   - decrease vanc to 1gm q48h
   - f/u cultures
   .
   #) Hypotension: Likely [**12-21**] sepsis from underlying lung infection.
   Currently on Levophed and vasopression.
   - continue to wean off pressors as tolerated
   - continue to treat underlying infection
   - monitor UOP, MAP, CVP
   - f/u cultures
   - hold metoprolol and lasix
   .
   #) Acid/base disturbances: gap closed. Continues to mild non-anion gap
   metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic metabolic
   acidosis.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct has been trending down. On admission Hct was 31.4. DAH
   given CXR infiltrate?
   - guaiac all stools
   - send Fe studies, B12, Folate, hemolysis labs
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome
   - per derm, reasonable to start clinda but resident will check with
   attending
   -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
   -d/c steroids per derm
   -f/u any new derm recs
   -no advil/motrin
   - HSV-1 postive perioral lesions per Derm, started Acyclovir for HSV
   perioral lesions, renally dose Acyclovir
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.0. Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis.  Also, could be prerenal from hypotension,
   dehydration.
   -renally dose medications
   - repeat UA urine lytes, consider renal consult
   -FeNa was 1.25% indicating instrinsic>prerenal etiology
   - increase free H2O flushes, check PM lytes
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged acidemia.
   Currently, sedated, unresponsive to voice or pain.
   -improved Neuro exam today with movement in all limbs in response to
   pain
   - order CT head to r/o acute pathology
   -continue thiamine
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Likely [**12-21**] volume depletion during diuresis.
   - continue free water flushes to 250cc q4h
   - PM lytes
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: patient in sinus here, holding metoprolol given
   hypotension.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism:
   -continue 37.5 mcg IV levothyroxine

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, presenting with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was initially improving but then experienced a worsening of his mental status, leading to intubation for respiratory failure and the initiation of dopamine for hypotension. He was transferred to another hospital for further management. The patient has been diagnosed with extensive left lower lobe pneumonia with a small parapneumonic effusion, and his condition has been complicated by sepsis, hypotension, acid-base disturbances, anemia, rash, renal failure, altered mental status, hypernatremia, transaminitis, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and hypothyroidism.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's underlying health conditions, such as HAP (Healthcare-associated pneumonia) or aspiration, may have contributed to his respiratory failure. ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome) is a possibility. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation.
2. Hypotension: Sepsis from the underlying lung infection is likely causing the patient's hypotension. The patient is currently being treated with Levophed and vasopressin.
3. Acid-Base Disturbances: The patient has a mild non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
4. Anemia: The patient

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was initially improving but experienced a worsening of mental status and respiratory status, leading to intubation.

The patient has been diagnosed with extensive left lower lobe pneumonia with a small parapneumonic effusion. There are multiple areas of ground-glass attenuation and minimal consolidation elsewhere in the lungs, indicating early multifocal spread of pneumonia. The chest CT also shows hydrostatic edema, anasarca, and ascites. There is a hyperdense liver, which may be related to amiodarone therapy. The CT head did not reveal any evidence of acute hemorrhage or major vascular territorial infarction.

The patient's blood cultures grew group B strep (GBS), and the respiratory culture showed moderate growth of beta streptococci, not group A. Legionella culture was negative, as well as fungal cultures. The OSH BAL showed group B strep.

The patient's condition is complicated by several medical complications, including respiratory failure likely due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) secondary to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or aspiration. Vasculitis in the lungs seems less likely given the absence of blood in the bronchus and stable hematocrit levels. The patient has hypotension likely secondary to sepsis from the underlying lung infection

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was intubated for worsening respiratory status and started on dopamine for hypotension. The patient's condition has been improving until Saturday when his mental status worsened. He was transferred to another hospital for management of respiratory failure and hypotension.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is likely experiencing ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome) due to HAP (healthcare-associated pneumonia) or aspiration. The TTE showed normal ejection fraction, ruling out CHF (congestive heart failure). The patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease). Vasculitis in the lungs is less likely given no blood seen on bronchoscopy and stable hematocrit.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely due to sepsis from the underlying lung infection. He is currently on Levophed and vasopressin. The plan is to continue to wean off pressors as tolerated, continue to treat the underlying infection, monitor urine output and systolic blood pressures, and follow up with cultures.
3. Acid/base disturbances: The patient continues to have anion gap metabolic acidosis, which is likely due to uremia (lactate is normal, not diabetic). The respiratory acidosis

   Assessment and Plan
   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and started on dopamine for hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   management of respiratory failure and hypotension.
   .
   #) SVT: pt was found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was
   hemodynamically unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on
   levophed. In terms of etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to
   infection, volume depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - cardioversion when pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic instability
   - change levophed to neo.
   - transfuse 2u pRBC for volume repletion
   - continue treatment for respiratory infection
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation,
   consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out non-group A strep and OSH
   sputum was positive with GBS. Unsure whether GBS would give a toxic
   shock syndrome picture and lead to ARDS.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o
   CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis
   in lungs less likely given no blood seen on bronch, stable HCT.
   ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   - advance ETT as the tube is too high
   - on PC, will decr RR further as pt appears to have autoPEEP and not
   able to breath out completely, and repeat ABG
   - continue Vanco/Cefepime/Cipro for HAP for now
   - consider decreasing vanc to 1gm q48h as vanc trough is 25.7, recheck
   vanc trough tomorrow
   - consult ID re antibiotic choice and whether clinda should be started
   to treat toxic shock syndrome
   - f/u cultures
   .
   #) sepsis: Pt meets the criteria for sepsis. The source of infection is
   likely pulmonary given CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. Other
   source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection at this
   time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. Pt has a coccyx
   ulcer but the wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has been
   negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - continue vanc/cefepime/cipro for now
   - f/u ID recs
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - f/u cultures
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   .
   #) Hypotension: Likely [**12-21**] sepsis from underlying lung infection.
   Currently on Levophed and vasopression.
   - change levophed to neo in the setting of SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - continue to treat underlying infection
   - monitor UOP, MAP, CVP
   - f/u cultures
   - hold metoprolol and lasix
   .
   #) Acid/base disturbances: gap closed. Continues to mild non-anion gap
   metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic metabolic
   acidosis.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct has been trending down. On admission Hct was 31.4. DDx
   includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic disease /
   inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools
   - send Fe studies, B12, Folate, hemolysis labs
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome
   - per derm, reasonable to start clinda but resident will check with
   attending
   -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
   -d/c
d steroids per derm
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   - HSV-1 postive perioral lesions per Derm, started Acyclovir for HSV
   perioral lesions, but it was d/c
d given HSV infection most likely does
   not contribute to the current presentation
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.0. Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely given neg [**Doctor First Name **] and
   ANCA, but if renal function continues to worsen would consider that
   possibility given his picture of respiratory failure, renal failure,
   vasculitic skin lesions and anemia.
   - renally dose medications
   - repeat UA urine lytes, consider renal consult if renal function
   continues to worse
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   Currently, sedated, no corneal or pupil reflexes, however pt does move
   extremities to pain. CT head was negative for any intracranial process.
   -neuro exam when sedation is lightened
   -continue thiamine
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Likely [**12-21**] volume depletion during diuresis.
   - increase  free water flushes to 250cc q3h from q4h
   - PM lytes
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: this morning was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), was
   condioverted
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick thyroid syndrome
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was intubated for worsening respiratory status and started on dopamine for hypotension. The patient's condition has been complicated by several medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has evidence of left lower lobe pneumonia with associated parapneumonic effusion on chest CT. Non-group A strep was grown from sputum culture, and group B strep was identified in oral secretions. These findings suggest an infectious etiology for his respiratory failure.

2. Septic shock: The patient meets the criteria for sepsis, likely due to the pulmonary infection. Other potential sources of infection include the gastrointestinal tract, but no evidence of GI infection is currently present.

3. Hypotension: The patient is likely experiencing septic shock secondary to the underlying lung infection. He is currently on Levophed and vasopressin for hemodynamic support.

4. Acid-base disturbances: The patient has a mild non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

5. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin concentration has been trending down, indicating anemia. The differential diagnosis includes gastrointestinal bleeding, anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, or disseminated intravascular coagulation.

6. Rash: The patient has a diffuse rash,

   Assessment and Plan
   84 yo male with admission with ARDS secondary to pneumonia +/-
   aspiration and now with persistent respiratory failure complicated by
   acute renal failure and recurrent tachycardia.  He has had some
   improved compliance and improved oxygenation with good support but with
   recurrent and persistent tachycardia patient also maintains worsening
   renal function with creatinine increased to 3.0.
   1)Respiratory Failure-This would appear to be more easily supported
   this morning with PCV levels and FIO2 able to be decreased
   -Will decrease rate and PEEP today as tolerated.
   -Goal Pplat is much closer to 25
   2)Sepsis-This, again is most likely related to pulmonary source with
   Strep species and have been able to wean pressors to off only
   transiently and now with return to persistent levophed requirement.
   This likely represents continued vasodilatory shock
   -Continue with broad spectrum ABX
   -Keep CVP at 12
   -Will change pressors to non-beta agonist
   -He has had some decrease in fever and WBC count
   3)Tachycardia--Patient with recurrent AVNRT this morning
refractory to
   adenosine but responsive to cardioversion at 50 Joules x2.  This is in
   the setting of continued requirement for pressor support and continued
   SIRS with pneumonia slow to resolve.  This presented during rounds this
   morning
   -Will assure volume replete
   -Will continue to treat sepsis
   -If recurrent will need to move to non-beta agonist pressor
   -Cardioversion as needed today
   4)Acute Renal Failure-
   -Patient with continued and persistence of elevation in creatinine
   -Urine flow has been borderline
   5)Altered Mental Status
Patient with persistent decreased
   responsiveness but in the setting of high ventilator requirements and
   recurrent tachycardia with need for cardioversion it has been difficult
   to get a sustained time of hold on sedation to complete exam.  Head CT
   is reassuring.
   -Minimize sedation as possible today
   -Follow up neuro exam

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure, sepsis, and acute renal failure. The patient has been in the ICU and is currently on mechanical ventilation with a PRES/AC mode. The vital signs show a heart rate of 81 bpm, blood pressure of 119/26 mmHg, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is in atrial fibrillation with a CVP of 34.7 mmHg.

The patient's recent lab results show a white blood cell count of 19.5 K/uL, hemoglobin of 7.6 g/dL, platelet count of 124 K/uL, creatinine of 3.0 mg/dL, blood glucose of 107 mg/dL, and potassium levels within normal range. The arterial blood gas shows a pH of 7.34, PaCO2 of 39 mmHg, PaO2 of 223, and oxygen saturation of 100%.

Imaging studies reveal pneumonia and consolidation in the left lung, as well as a small effusion. A head CT shows no bleed or infarction.

   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and started on dopamine for hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   management of respiratory failure and hypotension.
   .
   #) SVT: pt was found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was
   hemodynamically unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on
   levophed. In terms of etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to
   infection, volume depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - cardioversion when pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic instability
   - levophed was changed to neo.
   - continue treatment for respiratory infection
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation,
   consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out non-group A strep and OSH
   sputum was positive with GBS. Unsure whether GBS would give a toxic
   shock syndrome picture and lead to ARDS.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o
   CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis
   in lungs less likely given no blood seen on bronch, stable HCT.
   ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   - advance ETT as the tube is too high
   - on PC, will decr RR further as pt appears to have autoPEEP and not
   able to breath out completely, and repeat ABG
   - continue Vanco/Cefepime/Cipro for HAP for now
   - consider decreasing vanc to 1gm q48h as vanc trough is 25.7, recheck
   vanc trough tomorrow
   - consult ID re antibiotic choice and whether clinda should be started
   to treat toxic shock syndrome
   - f/u cultures
   .
   #) sepsis: Pt meets the criteria for sepsis. The source of infection is
   likely pulmonary given CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. Other
   source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection at this
   time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt
   is intermittently hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree
   of bowel ischemia leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a
   coccyx ulcer but the wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - continue vanc/cefepime/cipro for now
   - per ID, began penicillin G 4 million units IV q 4 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, continue the cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - Discontinued vancomycin, cefepime, and flagyl.
   - restarted acyclovir 10 mg/kg IV q 8 hours for empiric therapy.
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - follow lactate
   - f/u cultures, will need to send another set of urine and blood
   culture as the most recent ones are from [**8-4**] and [**8-3**]
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdoment if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Hypotension: Likely [**12-21**] sepsis from underlying lung infection.
   Currently on neo.
   - changed levophed to neo in the setting of SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - continue to treat underlying infection
   - monitor UOP, MAP, CVP
   - f/u cultures
   - hold metoprolol and lasix
   .
   #) Acid/base disturbances: gap closed. Continues to mild non-anion gap
   metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic metabolic
   acidosis.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct has been trending down. On admission Hct was 31.4. DDx
   includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic disease /
   inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed anemia of
   chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No evidence of
   hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal failure which
   also contributes to his anemia.
   - pt received 2u pRBC yesterday, Hct appropriately bumped. Goal Hct >30
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - re-started acyclovir per ID
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
   - d/c
d steroids per derm
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.0. Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely given neg [**Doctor First Name **] and
   ANCA, but if renal function continues to worsen would consider that
   possibility given his picture of respiratory failure, renal failure,
   vasculitic skin lesions and anemia.
   - renally dose medications
   - repeat UA urine lytes, consider renal consult if renal function
   continues to worse
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   Currently, sedated, no corneal or pupil reflexes, however pt does move
   extremities to pain. CT head was negative for any intracranial process.
   -neuro exam when sedation is lightened
   -continue thiamine
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Resolved. Likely [**12-21**] volume depletion during
   diuresis.
   - continue  free water flushes to 250cc q3h
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: this morning was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), was
   condioverted
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, who presented to the hospital with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was initially improving but then experienced a worsening of mental status, respiratory failure, and hypotension. The patient has been diagnosed with several conditions including SVT (supraventricular tachycardia), respiratory failure likely due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), sepsis, hypotension, metabolic acidosis, anemia, rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He has undergone multiple interventions including cardioversion, changes in antibiotics, and fluid management. The patient's current goals of care include treating underlying infections, managing organ dysfunction, and providing supportive care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Continued respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration or development of complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction: The patient's septic state and underlying comorbidities may lead to the involvement of other organs, resulting in complications like acute kidney injury (AKI) or hepatic dysfunction.
3. SVT recurrence: There is a possibility of recurrent SVT episodes, which can cause hemodynamic instability and potentially lead to arrhythmia-related complications.
4. Worsening renal function: The patient's renal

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was initially improving but experienced a worsening of mental status and respiratory status, leading to intubation. The patient has multiple medical complications including sepsis, respiratory failure, hypotension, acid-base disturbances, anemia, rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient meets the criteria for sepsis due to his underlying lung infection. The source of infection is likely pulmonary, and there may also be a possibility of bowel ischemia leading to bacteremia.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has evidence of lower lobe lung consolidation consistent with hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). There is also a risk of COPD exacerbation due to his smoking history.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely secondary to sepsis from the underlying lung infection.
4. Acid-Base Disturbances: The patient has mild non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, which is likely secondary to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
5. Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, and his Hct has been trending down. Renal failure may also contribute to his anemia.
6. Rash: The patient has a rash that is likely secondary to toxic shock syndrome

   Assessment and Plan
   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and started on dopamine for hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   management of respiratory failure and hypotension.
   .
   #) SVT: pt was found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was
   hemodynamically unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on
   levophed. In terms of etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to
   infection, volume depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - cardioversion when pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic instability
   - levophed was changed to neo.
   - per ID, began penicillin G 4 million units IV q 4 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, continue the cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation,
   consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out non-group A strep and OSH
   sputum was positive with GBS. Unsure whether GBS would give a toxic
   shock syndrome picture and lead to ARDS.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o
   CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis
   in lungs less likely given no blood seen on bronch, stable HCT.
   ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   - on PC, will decr RR further as pt appears to have autoPEEP and not
   able to breath out completely, and repeat ABG
   - per ID, began penicillin G 4 million units IV q 4 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, continue the cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - on acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: Pt meets the criteria for sepsis. The source of infection is
   likely pulmonary given CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. Other
   source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection at this
   time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt
   is intermittently hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree
   of bowel ischemia leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a
   coccyx ulcer but the wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - per ID, began penicillin G 4 million units IV q 4 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, continue the cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - Discontinued vancomycin, cefepime, and flagyl.
   - restarted acyclovir 10 mg/kg IV q 8 hours for empiric therapy.
   - f/u on Lyme IgG/IgM Antibody; Anaplasma phagocytophilum (human
   granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Blood Smear For Parasites;
   Babesia Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella
   zoster Antibody, IgM; Herpes 6 PCR
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - follow lactate
   - culture if spikes
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdoment if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Hypotension: Likely [**12-21**] sepsis from underlying lung infection.
   Currently on neo.
   - changed levophed to neo in the setting of SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - continue to treat underlying infection
   - monitor UOP, MAP, CVP
   - f/u cultures
   .
   #) Acid/base disturbances: gap closed. Continues to mild non-anion gap
   metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic metabolic
   acidosis.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct has been trending down, received 2u pRBC yesterday. On
   admission Hct was 31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive,
   anemia of chronic disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate.
   Fe studies revealed anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and
   folate are normal. No evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point.
   Patient also has renal failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - pt received 2u pRBC yesterday, Hct appropriately bumped. Goal Hct >30
   as he has SVT
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin rash
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - re-started acyclovir per ID
   - per derm, pt was started on triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin rash
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - d/c
d steroids per derm
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.0. Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely given neg [**Doctor First Name **] and
   ANCA, but if renal function continues to worsen would consider that
   possibility given his picture of respiratory failure, renal failure,
   vasculitic skin lesions and anemia.
   - renally dose medications
   - repeat UA urine lytes, consider renal consult if renal function
   continues to worse
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   Currently, sedated, no corneal or pupil reflexes, however pt does move
   extremities to pain. CT head was negative for any intracranial process.
   -neuro exam when sedation is lightened
   -continue thiamine
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Resolved. Likely [**12-21**] volume depletion during
   diuresis.
   - continue  free water flushes to 250cc q3h
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: this morning was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), was
   condioverted
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family
   ICU Care

Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was intubated for worsening respiratory status and started on dopamine for hypotension. The patient was transferred to another hospital for management of respiratory failure and hypotension.

The patient has experienced several medical complications, including:

1. Supraventricular Tachycardia (SVT): The patient had multiple episodes of SVT, which were likely caused by infection, volume depletion, and the use of levophed (a beta1 agonist). Cardioversion was performed when the patient was hemodynamically unstable.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's chest X-ray and CT scan showed evidence of left lower lobe consolidation, consistent with hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). Sputum culture grew non-group A strep, and OSH sputum was positive with Gram-negative bacilli (GBS). The patient is receiving appropriate antibiotics for GBS and gram-negative coverage.

3. Sepsis: The patient meets the criteria for sepsis, likely secondary to the pulmonary infection. Other potential sources of infection include the gastrointestinal tract, but there is no evidence of GI infection at this time.

4. Acid-Base Disturbances: The patient has mild non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU with multiple medical complications. The patient has throat cancer and is currently experiencing respiratory failure due to pneumonia. They also have a rash, which is unclear in its cause.

The patient underwent cardioversion/defibrillation multiple times for supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Their vital signs are relatively stable with a heart rate ranging from 66 to 164 bpm, blood pressure between 100/38 mmHg and 119/39 mmHg, respiratory rate between 19 and 31 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 100%.

The patient's fluid balance shows an intake of 5,718 mL and output of 745 mL since midnight. They are receiving various medications, including antibiotics (vancomycin, cefepime, metronidazole, ciprofloxacin), antivirals (acyclovir), and pain management medications (midazolam, fentanyl).

Laboratory results indicate leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 15.0 K/uL, slightly low hemoglobin at 9.3 g/dL, elevated potassium levels at 5.6 mg/dL, and normal creatinine levels at 1.2 mg/dL. Other lab results show mild alterations in electrolytes and liver function tests.

Radiology findings reveal worsening bibasilar infiltrates on chest X-ray.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 45-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU due to respiratory distress. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Upon admission, the patient required intubation and mechanical ventilation. He has been experiencing episodes of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), which have been managed with cardioversion. The patient also has hypernatremia (high sodium levels) and hypotension, but not in shock. He has impaired skin integrity, and there are concerns about acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or acute lung injury.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Prolonged intubation and mechanical ventilation can lead to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
2. The patient's impaired skin integrity increases the risk of pressure ulcers or bedsores.
3. ARDS or acute lung injury can progress to multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS), affecting other organs such as the kidneys, liver, and heart.
4. Supraventricular tachycardia may recur and require further intervention.
5. Hypernatremia needs to be closely monitored and managed to prevent complications like neurological dysfunction.
6. Hypotension may require ongoing monitoring and adjustment of fluid and medication therapy to maintain adequate blood pressure.
7. The patient's underlying hypertension and hyperlipidemia increase the risk of cardiovascular events.
8. Prolonged immobilization in the ICU can lead to deep vein thrombosis

The patient has been receiving various antibiotics and supportive care. His vital signs remain stable, but he has shown some improvement in his chest X-ray. However, he continues to require high ventilator settings.

1. Supraventricular Tachycardia (SVT): The patient is at risk for SVT, and pads have been placed for cardioversion if needed.
2. Pressor Needs Worsening: The patient's pressor needs have worsened over the past 24 hours, indicating a potential issue with hemodynamic stability.
3. Rash: The patient has developed a diffuse rash, which could be indicative of toxic shock syndrome or a hypersensitivity reaction to one of the medications.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory requirements remain high, suggesting ongoing respiratory failure despite ventilatory support.
5. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient may be at risk for developing ARDS due to severe pneumonia and respiratory failure.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia needs to be closely monitored and managed appropriately.
7. Non-gap Metabolic Acidosis: The patient has non-gap metabolic acidosis, which requires further evaluation and management.
8. Throat Cancer: Although currently inactive, the patient's history of throat cancer needs

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently in the ICU with multiple medical conditions. The patient has been diagnosed with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and is being monitored with pads for cardioversion as needed. The patient's blood pressure and heart rate are relatively stable, but there has been an increase in pressor needs over the past 24 hours.

The patient also has a rash with unclear cause and is receiving supportive care. There are concerns about pneumonia or respiratory failure due to high vent requirements. Antibiotics have been continued, and the plan is to wean the vent as tolerated.

The patient's renal function is slowly worsening, and there is ongoing concern about throat cancer, which is currently considered an inactive issue. The patient has been diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is being treated with bronchodilators.

Additionally, the patient has an active herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, for which acyclovir has been continued. The patient received a blood transfusion yesterday for anemia and will require further monitoring and follow-up.

The patient's nutritional needs are being met through NovaSource Renal (Full) at 35 mL/hour. The patient has arterial and multi-lumen lines in place for monitoring and medication administration. Prophylactic measures are being taken to prevent deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Overall, the patient's condition

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old male who presented to the hospital with symptoms of pneumonia. He was admitted to the ICU and intubated due to respiratory failure. The patient has been receiving various antibiotics, including vancomycin, cefepime, metronidazole, acyclovir, ciprofloxacin, clindamycin, and penicillin G potassium. He is also on infusions of fentanyl and phenylephrine, as well as heparin sodium for prophylaxis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1°C, heart rate of 67 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 108/39 mmHg to 122/42 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 100%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 20 mL/kg, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 12 cmH2O, fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%, and respiratory system compliance (RSBI) deferred due to PEEP >10.

Physical examination reveals diffuse rash, coarse lung sounds, hypoactive bowel sounds, trace edema in extremities, and unresponsive status with sedation. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 14.2 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hb) of 9.4 g/dL, creatinine (Cr) of 2.8 mg/dL, blood glucose of 124 mg/dL, and C-reactive protein (CRP) of 28.3 mg/dL. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows a pH of 7.27, partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) / fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) ratio of 265, and base excess (BE) of -9 mEq/L. Chest X-ray (CXR) shows improvement in left greater than right basilar opacities.

The patient has several medical complications, including supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), rash likely due to toxic shock syndrome, pneumonia/respiratory failure, acute kidney injury (ARF), throat cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, anemia, and non-gap metabolic acidosis. The patient's current plan includes supportive care, continuation of antibiotics, weaning off the ventilator as tolerated, and addressing each of the individual medical complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and started on dopamine for hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   management of respiratory failure and hypotension.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation,
   consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out non-group A strep and OSH
   sputum was positive with GBS. Unsure whether GBS would give a toxic
   shock syndrome picture and lead to ARDS.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o
   CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis
   in lungs less likely given no blood seen on bronch, stable HCT.
   ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   - on PC, will decr RR further as pt appears to have autoPEEP and not
   able to breath out completely, and repeat ABG
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: Pt meets the criteria for sepsis. The source of infection is
   likely pulmonary given CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. Other
   source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection at this
   time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt
   is intermittently hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree
   of bowel ischemia leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a
   coccyx ulcer but the wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection - f/u on Lyme IgG/IgM Antibody;
   Anaplasma phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM;
   Blood Smear For Parasites; Babesia Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus
   B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster Antibody, IgM; Herpes 6 PCR
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - follow lactate
   - culture if spikes
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdoment if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Hypotension: Likely [**12-21**] sepsis from underlying lung infection.
   Currently on neo.
   - changed levophed to neo in the setting of SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - continue to treat underlying infection
   - monitor UOP, MAP, CVP
   - f/u cultures
   .
   #) SVT: pt was found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was
   hemodynamically unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on
   levophed. In terms of etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to
   infection, volume depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - cardioversion when pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic instability
   - levophed was changed to neo.
   - per ID, began penicillin G 4 million units IV q 4 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, continue the cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   .
   #) Acid/base disturbances: gap closed. Continues to mild non-anion gap
   metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic metabolic
   acidosis.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct has been trending down, received 2u pRBC yesterday. On
   admission Hct was 31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive,
   anemia of chronic disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate.
   Fe studies revealed anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and
   folate are normal. No evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point.
   Patient also has renal failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - pt received 2u pRBC yesterday, Hct appropriately bumped. Goal Hct >30
   as he has SVT
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin rash
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - re-started acyclovir per ID
   - per derm, pt was started on triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin rash
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - d/c
d steroids per derm
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.2. Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely given neg [**Doctor First Name **] and
   ANCA, but if renal function continues to worsen would consider that
   possibility given his picture of respiratory failure, renal failure,
   vasculitic skin lesions and anemia.
   - renally dose medications
   - repeat UA urine lytes, consider renal consult if renal function
   continues to worse
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   Currently, sedated, no corneal or pupil reflexes, however pt does move
   extremities to pain. CT head was negative for any intracranial process.
   -neuro exam when sedation is lightened
   -continue thiamine
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Resolved. Likely [**12-21**] volume depletion during
   diuresis.
   - continue  free water flushes to 250cc q3h
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: this morning was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), was
   condioverted
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .

He was improving until Saturday when his mental status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status and started on dopamine for hypotension. He was transferred to Hospital11 for management of respiratory failure and hypotension.

The patient has multiple medical issues, including respiratory failure, sepsis, hypotension, SVT, acid-base disturbances, anemia, rash, renal failure, altered mental status, hypernatremia, transaminitis, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and hypothyroidism.

Respiratory failure is indicated by the patient's presentation with fever, worsening respiratory status, and evidence of lung consolidation on CXR and CT. Sputum culture grew non-group A strep and OSH sputum was positive with GBS. The patient is being treated with penicillin G, clindamycin, and ciprofloxacin.

Sepsis is suggested by the patient's presentation with fever, hypotension, and worsening mental status. The source of infection is likely pulmonary given the evidence of LLL pneumonia on imaging. Other potential sources of infection include GI, but no evidence of GI infection is noted at this time.

   Assessment and Plan
   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and started on dopamine for hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   management of respiratory failure, and now in multi-organ failure
   (pulm, cardiac/SVT, renal, derm)
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation,
   consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out non-group A strep and OSH
   sputum was positive with GBS. Unsure whether GBS would give a toxic
   shock syndrome picture and lead to ARDS.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o
   CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis
   in lungs less likely. ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   - on PC currently, will change back to AC today and see if he tolerates
   it. Get ABG to monitor respiratory status.
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection, as per ID this presentation
   could represent HSV generalized infection
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: Pt meets the criteria for sepsis. However, WBC trending
   down, and fever curve going down as well. The source of infection is
   likely pulmonary given CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. Other
   source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection at this
   time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt
   is intermittently hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree
   of bowel ischemia leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a
   coccyx ulcer but the wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u on Lyme IgG/IgM Antibody; Anaplasma phagocytophilum (human
   granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Blood Smear For Parasites;
   Babesia Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella
   zoster Antibody, IgM; Herpes 6 PCR
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - follow lactate
   - culture if spikes
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdoment if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Hypotension: Likely [**12-21**] sepsis from underlying lung infection.
   Currently on neo.
   - changed levophed to neo in the setting of SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - continue to treat underlying infection
   - monitor UOP, MAP, CVP
   - f/u cultures
   .
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 24 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - cardioversion when pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic instability
   - levophed was changed to neo.
   - per ID, began penicillin G 4 million units IV q 4 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, continue the cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   .
   #) Acid/base disturbances: gap closed. Continues to mild non-anion gap
   metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic metabolic
   acidosis and acute on chronic renal failure.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 2u pRBC on [**8-6**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct >30 as he has SVT
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin rash
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - re-started acyclovir per ID
   - per derm, pt was started on triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin rash
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - d/c
d steroids per derm
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.2. Most likely [**12-21**] ATN from
   hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely given neg [**Doctor First Name **] and
   ANCA, but if renal function continues to worsen would consider that
   possibility given his picture of respiratory failure, renal failure,
   vasculitic skin lesions and anemia.
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin rash, and  will
   aggressively resuscitate with LR today
   - renally dose medications
   - repeat UA urine lytes, consider renal consult if renal function
   continues to worse
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   Currently, sedated, no corneal or pupil reflexes, however pt does move
   extremities to pain. CT head was negative for any intracranial process.
   -neuro exam when sedation is lightened
   -continue thiamine
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Resolved. Likely [**12-21**] volume depletion during
   diuresis.
   - change  free water flushes from 250cc q3h to 250cc q6h
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - Need to have a family discussion in the coming week to further
   clarify goals of care, and update the family on patient status.
   Currently stable but low hope to recover to baseline
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NovaSource Renal (Full) - [**2100-8-7**] 10:28 PM 35 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:  ISS

   DVT: SC Heparin
   Stress ulcer:  PPI
   VAP:  VAP bundle

   Communication:  Comments: family. Need to have a family discussion in
   the coming week to further clarify goals of care, and update the family
   on patient status. Currently stable but low hope to recover to baseline
   Code status: FULL
   Disposition: continue ICU care
Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. The patient's condition initially improved until Saturday when his mental status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status. He was transferred to this hospital for management of respiratory failure and is now in multi-organ failure (pulmonary, cardiac/SVT, renal, dermal).

The patient's current medical conditions include respiratory failure, sepsis, hypotension, supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), metabolic acidosis, anemia, rash, and renal failure. The patient has been diagnosed with hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) and tested positive for Group B Streptococcus (GBS) in his sputum. He has also shown signs of toxic shock syndrome (TSS). The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to the underlying lung infection, and his renal failure is likely secondary to hypotension from sepsis. The patient's altered mental status is likely due to prolonged sepsis and sedation.

The patient has received various treatments including penicillin G, clindamycin, ciprofloxacin, acyclovir, and heparin sodium for prophylaxis. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.1°C, heart rate of 67 bpm, blood pressure of 108/39 mm

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer. He presented to the hospital with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. Initially, he showed improvement but then his mental status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status. He was transferred to another hospital for management of respiratory failure and is now in multi-organ failure (pulmonary, cardiac/SVT, renal, dermal).

The patient has several medical complications including respiratory failure, sepsis, hypotension, supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), acid-base disturbances, anemia, rash, renal failure, and altered mental status.

Respiratory failure is likely due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) with non-group A strep and gram-negative bacilli identified in the sputum culture. The patient is being treated with penicillin G, clindamycin, and ciprofloxacin.

Sepsis is suspected, with the source of infection likely pulmonary given the evidence of LLL pneumonia on imaging. Other sources of infection include the gastrointestinal tract, but there is no evidence of GI infection at this time.

Hypotension is likely due to sepsis from the underlying lung infection. The patient is currently on neomycin, and it is planned to continue treating the underlying infection.

SVT was present but did not recur during the past 24 hours. It

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is an 84-year-old male admitted with hypoxemic respiratory failure.
- He has been moved to the ICU due to persistent respiratory failure, complicated by sepsis and worsening renal failure.
- Group B strep has been found in the sputum, which is likely the pathogen causing the infection and may be linked to a rash.
- Empiric treatment for toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is being considered.
- The patient has continued to deteriorate despite maximal medical therapy.
- The current assessment suggests that this may be an evolution of hospital-acquired pneumonia with subsequent sepsis and renal failure caused by Group B strep infection in the pulmonary system.
- The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and the family has been updated on the situation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing persistent hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely due to pneumonia and a small/moderate pleural effusion. He will continue to receive assisted ventilation support.
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis caused by Group B strep. Antibiotics have been started to cover for inhibition of toxin production.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's renal function has worsened, and measures will be taken to minimize volume as possible with current sepsis. Renal replacement therapy and supportive care will be considered.
4. Supraventricular Tachycardia

   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and started on dopamine for hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   management of respiratory failure, and now in multi-organ failure
   (pulm, cardiac/SVT, renal, derm)
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation,
   consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out non-group A strep and OSH
   sputum was positive with GBS.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o CHF. Patient's
   smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis in lungs less
   likely- ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   - on  AC currently today
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS) (day4), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day3) to
   inhibit toxin production, and cipro (day 6) for gram-negative
   coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection, as per ID this presentation
   could represent HSV generalized infection
   - added doxy per ID recs
   - f/u cultures here and from OSH
   - if no RMSF from OSH,  d/c doxy
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: Pt meets the criteria for sepsis. However, WBC trending
   down, and fever curve going down as well. The source of infection is
   likely pulmonary given CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. Other
   source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection at this
   time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt
   is intermittently hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree
   of bowel ischemia leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a
   coccyx ulcer but the wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - Lyme IgG/IgM Antibody neg; f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma phagocytophilum
   (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Blood Smear For
   Parasites; Babesia Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies;
   Varicella zoster Antibody, IgM; Herpes 6 PCR
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - follow lactate
   - culture if spikes
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdomen if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Hypotension: Likely [**12-21**] sepsis from underlying lung infection.
   Currently on neo and vasopressin.
   - avoid levophed given recent SVT
   - continue to treat underlying infection
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - f/u cultures
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: gap 11, albumin 1.7, so continues to have an
   anion gap, likely due to renal failure. Delta delta 0.52, so also has a
   non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic
   metabolic acidosis.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.2. has stablized.  Most
   likely [**12-21**] ATN from hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely
   given neg [**Doctor First Name **] and ANCA, but if renal function continues to worsen would
   consider that possibility given his picture of respiratory failure,
   renal failure, vasculitic skin lesions and anemia.
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin rash, and  will
   aggressively resuscitate with LR today
   - renally dose medications
   - consider renal consult if renal function continues to worse
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin rash. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - re-started acyclovir per ID
   - per derm, pt was started on triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin rash
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - d/c
d steroids per derm
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p free water
   flushes q6h. now hyponatremic.
   - d/c free water flushes 250cc q6h
   - continue to monitor
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 24 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - levophed was changed to neo.
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 2u pRBC on [**8-6**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct >30 as he has SVT
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   Currently, sedated, no corneal or pupil reflexes, however pt does move
   extremities to pain. CT head was negative for any intracranial process.
   -neuro exam when sedation is lightened
   -continue thiamine
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - family mtg Tuesday
   ICU Care
