Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was improving until Saturday when his mental status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status and started on dopamine for hypotension. He was transferred to the ICU for management of respiratory failure and now has multi-organ failure (pulmonary, cardiac/SVT, renal, dermal).

Potential medical complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has evidence of left lower lobe pneumonia on CXR and CT, which may be contributing to his respiratory failure. He is currently on mechanical ventilation with PRVC/AC mode.
2. Sepsis: The patient meets the criteria for sepsis, likely due to the underlying lung infection. His blood cultures have been negative, and he has received broad-spectrum antibiotics.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has an anion gap metabolic acidosis, possibly due to renal failure.
4. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, indicating renal dysfunction, which may be due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) from hypotension during sepsis.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient had hypernatremia initially but has now developed hyponatremia following free water flushes.
6. Skin rash: The patient has a diffuse pustular drug rash

   Assessment and Plan
   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and started on dopamine for hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   management of respiratory failure, and now in multi-organ failure
   (pulm, cardiac/SVT, renal, derm)
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation,
   consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out non-group A strep and OSH
   sputum was positive with GBS.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o CHF. Patient's
   smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis in lungs less
   likely- ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   - on  AC currently today
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day1:
   [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production, and cipro (day 1: [**8-3**]) for
   gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per ID this
   presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - added doxy per ID recs (day1: [**8-8**])
   - f/u cultures here and from OSH
   - if no RMSF from OSH,  d/c doxy
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: Pt meets the criteria for sepsis. However, WBC trending
   down, and fever curve going down as well. The source of infection is
   likely pulmonary given CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. Other
   source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection at this
   time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt
   is intermittently hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree
   of bowel ischemia leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a
   coccyx ulcer but the wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - Lyme IgG/IgM Antibody neg; f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma phagocytophilum
   (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Blood Smear For
   Parasites; Babesia Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies;
   Varicella zoster Antibody, IgM; Herpes 6 PCR
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - follow lactate
   - culture if spikes
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdomen if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Hypotension: Likely [**12-21**] sepsis from underlying lung infection.
   Currently on neo and vasopressin.
   - avoid levophed given recent SVT
   - continue to treat underlying infection
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - f/u cultures
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: gap 11, albumin 1.7, so continues to have an
   anion gap, likely due to renal failure. Delta delta 0.52, so also has a
   non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic
   metabolic acidosis.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.2. has stablized.  Most
   likely [**12-21**] ATN from hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely
   given neg [**Doctor First Name **] and ANCA, but if renal function continues to worsen would
   consider that possibility given his picture of respiratory failure,
   renal failure, vasculitic skin lesions and anemia.
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin rash, and  will
   aggressively resuscitate with LR today
   - renally dose medications
   - consider renal consult if renal function continues to worse
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin rash. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - re-started acyclovir per ID
   - per derm, pt was started on triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin rash
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - d/c
d steroids per derm
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p free water
   flushes q6h. now hyponatremic.
   - d/c free water flushes 250cc q6h
   - continue to monitor
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 24 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - levophed was changed to neo.
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 2u pRBC on [**8-6**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct >30 as he has SVT
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   Currently, sedated, no corneal or pupil reflexes, however pt does move
   extremities to pain. CT head was negative for any intracranial process.
   -neuro exam when sedation is lightened
   -continue thiamine
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - family mtg Tuesday
   ICU Care

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was improving until Saturday when his mental status worsened and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status and started on dopamine for hypotension. The patient was transferred to another hospital for management of respiratory failure and now presents with multi-organ failure (pulmonary, cardiac, renal, dermal).

The patient has multiple medical complications including respiratory failure, sepsis, hypotension, metabolic acidosis, renal failure, rash, hyponatremia, supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), anemia, altered mental status, transaminitis, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and hypothyroidism.

The patient's current medications include penicillin G, clindamycin, ciprofloxacin, acyclovir, vasopressin, phenylephrine, midazolam, fentanyl, pantoprazole, and heparin sodium.

The patient's recent lab results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, increased creatinine, elevated lactate levels, and abnormal electrolyte levels.

The patient's imaging studies reveal bilateral pleural effusion, persistent left perihilar fullness, and likely infiltrate on chest X-ray. A CT scan of the lungs shows

2. Sepsis: The patient meets the criteria for sepsis, likely due to pulmonary infection. Blood cultures have been negative, and the source of infection may be gastrointestinal, although there is no evidence of GI infection at this time.

3. Hypotension: The patient is hypotensive and likely has septic shock from the underlying lung infection. The patient is currently on neo and vasopressin.

   smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis in lungs less
   likely- ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   - on  AC currently, will decrease rate from 24 to 18, and monitor ABG
   to see if ventilation adequate
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day1:
   [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production, and cipro (day 1: [**8-3**]) for
   gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per ID this

   - added doxy per ID recs (day1: [**8-8**]);  if no RMSF from OSH,  d/c doxy

   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.

   production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was improving until Saturday when his mental status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status. The patient is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications. 

Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has evidence of left lower lobe pneumonia, and his respiratory status has worsened, leading to intubation. He is currently on assisted ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient meets the criteria for sepsis, with a likely source of infection being pulmonary due to evidence of pneumonia on imaging. Other potential sources include gastrointestinal infections, but no evidence of GI infection is present at this time.
3. Hypotension: The patient is hypotensive and requires vasopressor support. The likely cause of hypotension is septic shock secondary to the underlying lung infection.
4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has an anion gap metabolic acidosis likely due to renal failure. There is also a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, possibly secondary to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
5. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, indicating renal failure. This is most likely acute tubular necrosis (ATN) from hypotension during sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely.
6.

   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and started on dopamine for hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for
   management of respiratory failure, and now with renal failure as well.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation,
   consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out GBS.  Patient received
   lots of IVF yesterday for hypotension, and this AM the CXR appeared
   more volume overloaded. TTE showed normal EF, r/o CHF. Patient's
   smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis in lungs less
   likely- ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   - on  AC currently, will decrease rate from 24 to 18, and monitor ABG
   to see if ventilation adequate
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day1:
   [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production, and cipro (day 1: [**8-3**]) for
   gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per ID this
   presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - added doxy per ID recs (day1: [**8-8**]);  if no RMSF from OSH,  d/c doxy
   - f/u cultures here and from OSH
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: Pt meets the criteria for sepsis. The source of infection is
   likely pulmonary given CXR and CT evidence of LLL pneumonia. Other
   source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection at this
   time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt
   is intermittently hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree
   of bowel ischemia leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a
   coccyx ulcer but the wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - Lyme IgG/IgM Antibody neg; f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma phagocytophilum
   (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Blood Smear For
   Parasites; Babesia Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies;
   Varicella zoster Antibody, IgM; Herpes 6 PCR
   - continue to monitor, goal SBP>85 (not , UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and
   ScvO2 >70%
   - follow lactate
   - culture if spikes
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdomen if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Hypotension: Likely [**12-21**] sepsis from underlying lung infection.
   Currently on neo and vasopressin.
   - avoid levophed given recent SVT
   - continue to treat underlying infection
   - continue to monitor, goal MAP>65, UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and ScvO2
   >70%
   - f/u cultures
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: gap 11, albumin 1.7, so continues to have an
   anion gap, likely due to renal failure. Delta delta 0.52, so also has a
   non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic
   metabolic acidosis.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.2. has stablized.  Most
   likely [**12-21**] ATN from hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely
   given neg [**Doctor First Name **] and ANCA, but if renal function continues to worsen would
   consider that possibility given his picture of respiratory failure,
   renal failure, vasculitic skin lesions and anemia.
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin rash, and  will
   aggressively resuscitate with LR today
   - renally dose medications
   - consider renal consult if renal function continues to worse
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin rash. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - re-started acyclovir per ID
   - per derm, pt was started on triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin rash
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - d/c
d steroids per derm
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p free water
   flushes q6h. now hyponatremic.
   - d/c free water flushes 250cc q6h
   - continue to monitor
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 24 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - levophed was changed to neo.
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 2u pRBC on [**8-6**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct >30 as he has SVT
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   Currently, sedated, no corneal or pupil reflexes, however pt does move
   extremities to pain. CT head was negative for any intracranial process.
   -neuro exam when sedation is lightened
   -continue thiamine
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - family mtg Tuesday

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure and sepsis. The patient was admitted to the hospital with a bullous rash and later developed significant hypoxemic respiratory failure due to left-sided pneumonia. He has shown some improvement in compliance and capacity to wean off ventilator support.

However, the patient's course has been complicated by acute renal failure, persistent hypotension, and a continued septic shock state. He requires two pressors to maintain blood pressure and is currently on midazolam, fentanyl, vasopressin, and phenylephrine infusions.

The patient also has respiratory failure with persistent hypoxia but improved oxygen requirements. He has mild respiratory alkalosis and decreased respiratory responsiveness. An ABG analysis showed a metabolic acidosis. The plan is to trial a decrease in respiratory rate to 18 and monitor the response.

Additionally, the patient has acute renal failure with a plateaued creatinine level. Measures will be taken to improve metabolic acidosis and closely monitor urine output for signs of recovery.

The patient is also experiencing metabolic acidosis, both non-gap and anion gap types. The plan includes moving to lactated Ringer's solution for fluid support and continuing to support renal function with adequate fluid delivery.

Finally, the patient has a rash that will be managed with creams prescribed by dermatology, and the differential diagnosis will be expanded upon, considering interventions.

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, presenting with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was admitted to the ICU due to respiratory failure caused by hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) and sepsis. The patient's condition is complicated by several medical complications, including metabolic acidosis, renal failure, anemia, hyponatremia, supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, and altered mental status.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient has an anion gap metabolic acidosis likely due to renal failure and lactic acidosis. It is important to monitor the patient's acid-base balance and continue to provide appropriate treatment.
2. Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are increasing, indicating worsening renal function. Aggressive fluid resuscitation with lactated Ringer's solution (LR) should be continued to maintain proper kidney perfusion. Renal dosing of medications and consideration of a renal consult if renal function continues to worsen are necessary.
3. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which could be due to gastrointestinal bleeding, anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, or acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Further evaluation, including guaiac testing of stools and monitoring of hemoglobin levels, is needed. Renal function should be supported to

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was initially improving until his mental status worsened, leading to intubation for respiratory failure and hypotension. The patient was transferred to the ICU for management of respiratory failure.

Assessment:
1) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation, consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out GBS. The patient received lots of IVF yesterday, and this morning the CXR appeared more volume overloaded. TTE showed normal EF, ruling out CHF. The patient's smoking history puts him at risk for COPD. Vasculitis in the lungs is less likely, as ANCA/Doctor's Last Name are negative.
- Continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
- Continue acyclovir for HSV infection.
- Follow ID recs.
- Goal SBP >85, UOP >30cc/hr, CVP >8, and ScvO2 >70%.
- Monitor lactate.
- Culture if spikes.
- Continue wound care for coccyx ulcer.
- Consider CT abdomen if the patient does not improve.

   Assessment and Plan
   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status who was improving until Saturday when his mental
   status worsened, and he was intubated for worsening respiratory status
   and hypotension.  Transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] for management of respiratory
   failure.
   #) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation,
   consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out GBS.  Patient received
   lots of IVF yesterday for hypotension, and this AM the CXR appeared
   more volume overloaded. TTE showed normal EF, r/o CHF. Patient's
   smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.  Vasculitis in lungs less
   likely- ANCA/[**Doctor First Name **] are neg.
   - on  AC currently, rate decreasde from 24 to 18, and monitor ABG to
   see if ventilation adequate
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day1:
   [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production, and cipro (day 1: [**8-3**]) for
   gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per ID this
   presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - added doxy per ID recs (day1: [**8-8**]);  if no RMSF from OSH,  d/c doxy
   - f/u cultures here and from OSH
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given CXR and CT
   evidence of LLL pneumonia.   Received 3L IVF overnight, with addition
   of levophed due to SBP in the 70s.  Levophed was added and once
   pressures were stabilized, neo was weaned off.
   Other source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection
   at this time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt
   is intermittently hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree
   of bowel ischemia leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a
   coccyx ulcer but the wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (the drug of choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to
   inhibit toxin production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel: Lyme IgG/IgM Antibody neg;
   f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia
   [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Blood Smear For Parasites; Babesia Antibodies, IgG and
   IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster Antibody, IgM; Herpes
   6 PCR
   - continue to monitor, goal SBP>85 (not , UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and
   ScvO2 >70%
   - follow lactate
   - culture if spikes
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdomen if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: gap 11, albumin 1.7, so continues to have an
   anion gap, likely due to renal failure. Delta delta 0.52, so also has a
   non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to hyperchloremic
   metabolic acidosis.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.2. has stablized.  Most
   likely [**12-21**] ATN from hypotension from sepsis. Vasculitis is less likely
   given neg [**Doctor First Name **] and ANCA, but if renal function continues to worsen would
   consider that possibility given his picture of respiratory failure,
   renal failure, vasculitic skin lesions and anemia.
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin rash, and  will
   aggressively resuscitate with LR today
   - renally dose medications
   - consider renal consult if renal function continues to worse
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin rash. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis.
   - derm path from [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction: consider
   drug-induced or viral etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome cannot be
   exluded.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin rash
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h. now hyponatremic.
   - d/c free water flushes 250cc q6h
   - continue to monitor
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - now that levophed restarted, need to monitor
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 2u pRBC on [**8-6**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct >30 as he has SVT
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   Currently, sedated, no corneal or pupil reflexes, however pt does move
   extremities to pain. CT head was negative for any intracranial process.
   -neuro exam when sedation is lightened
   -continue thiamine
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - family mtg yesterday: family has a
wait and see
 approach

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was intubated for worsening respiratory status and hypotension. The patient's condition improved until Saturday when his mental status worsened, and he was transferred to another hospital for management of respiratory failure. The patient has multiple medical complications including respiratory failure due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) with positive sputum culture for Group B Streptococcus (GBS), sepsis, metabolic acidosis, renal failure, skin rash, hyponatremia, supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), anemia, altered mental status, transaminitis, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and hypothyroidism. The patient is currently receiving various treatments including antibiotics for GBS infection, vasopressors for hypotension, renal dose medications, and wound care for a coccyx ulcer. The patient's family has a wait-and-see approach regarding his care.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. worsening respiratory failure due to ongoing HAP
2. progression of sepsis leading to organ dysfunction
3. deterioration of renal function
4. development of acute kidney injury (AKI)
5. worsening metabolic acidosis
6. skin breakdown or infection at the site of the coc

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who presented with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He is currently admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, septic shock, acute renal failure, supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), and impaired skin integrity.

The patient has several ongoing medical issues and complications. These include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has evidence of left lower lobe pneumonia on chest X-ray and CT scan, consistent with hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). Sputum culture grew Group B streptococcus, pending sensitivities. The patient received 3 liters of IV fluids overnight and levophed was added due to low blood pressure. Levophed was weaned off once pressures were stabilized, and now the patient is on norepinephrine and vasopressin.

2. Sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given the evidence of LLL pneumonia. The patient is being treated with antibiotics, including penicillin G for Group B streptococcus, clindamycin to inhibit toxin production, and ciprofloxacin for gram-negative coverage. Acyclovir has also been started for HSV infection.

3. Renal Failure: The patient has an elevated creatinine level of 3.2, indicating acute renal failure. This is likely due to hypotension from sepsis. The patient is

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who presented to the hospital with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He has been diagnosed with respiratory failure due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) caused by Group B Streptococcus (GBS). The patient also has a generalized HSV infection, as indicated by positive HSV cultures from the nasopharynx and lip. He is currently being treated with penicillin G, clindamycin, and acyclovir. The patient's sepsis is suspected to be pulmonary in origin, with possible bowel ischemia contributing to bacteremia. His metabolic acidosis is likely due to renal failure and lactic acidosis. He has renal failure, likely due to hypotension from sepsis, and his anion gap has improved significantly. The patient's skin condition is being managed with clindamycin and acyclovir, and his wound care includes triamcinolone ointment and Aquafor. His altered mental status may be due to HSV encephalitis, prolonged sedation, or sepsis. Further imaging and lumbar puncture may be considered. The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic disease/inflammation, and his hyponatremia has resolved. He experienced supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) but is currently stable, and his transaminitis

   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who presented on [**7-24**] to [**Hospital1 **] with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure and
   altered mental status.
   #) Respiratory failure: CXR and CT evidence of LLL consolidation,
   consistent with HAP. Sputum culture grew out GBS, pending
   sensitivities.  s/p 3L LR and CXR showing pleural effusions. TTE showed
   normal EF, r/o CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at risk for
   COPD.
   - on  AC currently, rate decreasd from 24 to 18, and monitor ABG to see
   if ventilation adequate
   - continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (the drug of
   choice for GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day1:
   [**8-6**]) to inhibit toxin production
   - d/c Cipro per ID
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per ID this
   presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - added doxy per ID recs (day1: [**8-8**]);  if no RMSF from OSH,  d/c doxy
   - f/u cultures here and from OSH
   - f/u on ID recs
   .
   #) sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given CXR and CT
   evidence of LLL pneumonia.   Received 3L IVF overnight, with addition
   of levophed due to SBP in the 70s.  Levophed was added and once
   pressures were stabilized, neo was weaned off.  Now on levo and vaso.
   Other source of infection includes GI but no evidence of GI infection
   at this time, no diarrhea noted. KUB on [**8-3**] showed small amount of
   pericholecystic fluid, but no cholecystitis was seen. However, given pt
   is intermittently hypotensive, it is possible that pt has some degree
   of bowel ischemia leading to bacteremia. UA was negative. Pt has a
   coccyx ulcer but the wound does not appear infected. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so wouldn
t get at CT sinus at this point.
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (the drug of choice for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to
   inhibit toxin production, and cipro for gram-negative coverage.
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel: Lyme IgG/IgM Antibody neg;
   f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia
   [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Blood Smear For Parasites; BabTITLE:
   esia Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella
   zoster Antibody, IgM; Herpes 6 PCR
   - continue to monitor, goal SBP>85 (not , UOP>30cc/hr, CVP >[**8-30**] and
   ScvO2 >70%
   - follow lactate
   - culture if spikes
   - continue wound care for coccyx ulcer
   - would consider CT abdomen if pt does not improve
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis: gap 11, albumin 1.7, so continues to have an
   anion gap, likely due to renal failure and lactic acidosis. Also
   history of non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to
   hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis from IVF.
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr trending up 1.9---3.2
2.8.  Most likely [**12-21**] ATN
   from hypotension from sepsis.
   - support blood pressure for proper profusion of kidneys
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin rash, and  will
   aggressively resuscitate with LR today
   - renally dose medications
   - consider renal consult if renal function continues to worse
   .
   #) Rash: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome. Per derm, cefepime was d/c
d as possibly
   contributing to the worsening skin rash. Per derm, this is either GBS,
   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis.
   - derm path from [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction: consider
   drug-induced or viral etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome cannot be
   exluded.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin rash
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h. now hyponatremic with Na of 128..
   - d/c free water flushes 250cc q6h
   - continue to monitor
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - now that levophed restarted, need to monitor
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 2u pRBC on [**8-6**]. On admission Hct was

   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools

   .
   #) Altered mental status: Stable.  Likely [**12-21**] sedation and prolonged

   does move extremities to pain. CT head was negative for any
   intracranial process.
   -neuro exam when sedation is lightened
   -continue thiamine

   - continue to monitor on tele

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, presenting with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He was admitted to the hospital on [**7-24**] and diagnosed with respiratory failure due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), sepsis, acute renal failure, and impaired skin integrity. The patient has been receiving various treatments including antibiotics, antivirals, and supportive care. His current vital signs show stable blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation. The patient's laboratory results indicate abnormalities in electrolytes, kidney function, and liver function. Imaging studies reveal bilateral pleural effusion and likely infiltrate in the left lower lobe of the lung. The patient's medical team has made several decisions regarding his care, including continuing penicillin G and clindamycin for suspected Group B Streptococcus infection, discontinuing ciprofloxacin, initiating acyclovir for herpes virus infection, and restarting TF. Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening of respiratory failure, further deterioration of renal function, development of additional infections, and cardiovascular instability.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male admitted to the ICU with sepsis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and persistent alteration of mental status. The patient's current condition and potential medical complications are as follows:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has persistent high requirements for ventilator support but has been able to decrease PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure). The plan is to move to pressure support ventilation (PSV) at 15-20 with continued PEEP at 5.

2. Septic Shock: The infectious source is led by group B strep, with sensitivities noted on BAL (bronchoalveolar lavage) specimen and sputum. The patient is already on antibiotics (penicillin G, clindamycin, doxycycline, and acyclovir) and will continue pressor support with Levophed and Vasopressin.

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine has plateaued, but there is a failure to improve. There is severe metabolic acidosis, and bicarbonate will be used as needed. Dialysis is being held for now due to the ability to improve ventilator support levels.

4. Altered Mental Status: The patient shows some response to pain and spontaneous movement, but there is significant concern for persistent decorticate posturing. A CT scan is planned.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
- SUPRAVENT

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

- The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer.
- He presented with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status.
- He has been intubated for 12 days and is currently on pressure support (PS) due to hypotension.
- His blood cultures are pending, and he has tested positive for HSV infection from two sources (nasopharynx and lip).
- He also has a history of smoking, which puts him at risk for COPD.
- The source of infection is likely pulmonary given the evidence of LLL consolidation on CXR and CT.
- Other sources of infection include GI, but no evidence of GI infection is currently noted.
- The patient's sepsis is being treated with penicillin G, clindamycin, and ciprofloxacin.
- His metabolic acidosis is likely due to renal failure and lactic acidosis.
- He has renal failure with a creatinine level of 2.9 to 3.0, most likely due to hypotension from sepsis.
- His skin condition is worsening, with a diagnosis of leukoclastic vasculitis or toxic shock syndrome.
- He has altered mental status with some stereotypical decorticate reflexes, possibly due to HSV encephalitis.
- His anemia is likely secondary

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, who presented to the hospital with fever, diffuse desquamating rash, renal failure, and altered mental status. He has multiple medical complications including respiratory failure due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) and a positive Gram stain for Group B Streptococcus (GBS). He also has sepsis with likely pulmonary source, HSV infection, and metabolic acidosis. The patient has renal failure likely due to hypotension from sepsis. Other conditions include leukoclastic vasculitis, altered mental status possibly due to HSV encephalitis or prolonged sepsis, anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, hyponatremia, supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), and transaminitis.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, worsening sepsis leading to organ dysfunction, progression of renal failure, worsening metabolic acidosis, worsening anemia, recurrent SVT, and further deterioration in mental status.

Summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU: The patient's respiratory failure is secondary to generalized HSV infection and HAP. He has been treated with penicillin G and clindamycin to inhibit toxin production and ciprofloxacin for gram-negative coverage. Acyclovir has been continued for HSV infection. The patient's sepsis is being treated with appropriate antibiotics, and his renal function is being monitored.

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male admitted for respiratory failure and sepsis, now complicated by persistent hypotension and slow-to-improve mental status. The patient has persistent hypotension and has been unable to achieve hemodynamic stability, raising the question of potential compromise of adrenal function in the setting of disseminated HSV infection. If this is true, steroid replacement therapy may be necessary, driven by [**Last Name (un)**] stim testing.

The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory Failure: Secondary to pneumonia with left lower lobe involvement. There is some radiographic improvement, so the plan is to decrease RR to 14 and Vt to 500, continue to Rx infectious sources, and monitor improvement in lung mechanics and oxygenation.

2. Sepsis: The patient is currently on levophed and vasopressin. The plan is to wean pressors at tolerated today, with a trial fluid bolus today and moving to decrease pressor and repeat until able to wean pressors to off. Maintenance fluid may be needed if able to stabilize. The source of infection is Strep Pneumonia, and antibiotics will be continued with PCN G/Clindamycine. Acyclovir will also be administered due to HSV infection and possible adrenal insufficiency.

3. Renal Failure: There has been an improvement in non-gap acidosis, and urine output is improving. The plan is to enhance volume

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, who presented with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating skin lesions, renal failure, and altered mental status. The patient has been diagnosed with hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) and has tested positive for Group B Streptococcus (GBS) in his sputum culture. He also has a generalized HSV infection from two sources (nasopharynx and lip). The patient's respiratory failure could potentially be secondary to the generalized HSV infection.

The patient's sepsis is likely due to pulmonary infection, with evidence of consolidation on chest X-ray and CT. The source of infection may be gastrointestinal as well, but there is no current evidence of GI infection. The patient has been treated with penicillin G, clindamycin, and ciprofloxacin for GBS and pulmonary infection.

The patient also has metabolic acidosis, likely due to renal failure and lactic acidosis. Renal function is stable with a creatinine level of 2.9 to 3.0, indicating possible acute tubular necrosis from hypotension caused by sepsis.

The patient has leukoclastic vasculitis on his lower extremities, which may be related to toxic shock syndrome or a drug reaction. He is being treated with clindamycin to inhibit toxin production and acyclovir for HSV infection.

The patient's altered mental status is likely due

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and diffuse desquamating rash. The patient has multiple comorbidities including COPD, renal failure, and altered mental status. The patient's current condition is as follows:

- Respiratory: The patient has pneumonia, which is improving with treatment. He is on mechanical ventilation with PRVC/AC mode, FiO2 of 40%, PEEP of 5 cmH2O, and tidal volume of 550 mL. The patient's ABG shows a pH of 7.26, PaCO2 of 34 mmHg, PaO2 of 273 mmHg, and HCO3- of 16 mEq/L.

- Cardiovascular: The patient has hypotension and requires vasopressors (norepinephrine and vasopressin). The patient's mean arterial pressure (MAP) is around 55-65 mmHg.

- Renal: The patient has anemia of chronic disease/inflammation with a hemoglobin level of 7.5 g/dL. The patient received 1 unit of packed red blood cells (pRBC) on 08/13. The patient's creatinine is slowly improving, suggesting possible acute tubular necrosis (ATN) from hypotension during sepsis.

- Metabolic: The patient has metabolic acidosis with an anion gap

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male admitted for respiratory failure, sepsis, and suspected disseminated HSV infection. He has multiorgan failure, including respiratory failure, renal failure, shock, acidosis, and impaired skin integrity. The patient's condition remains unstable despite broad-spectrum antibiotics. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: Secondary to pneumonia with left lower lobe involvement. Improvement is observed in lung mechanics and oxygenation.
2. Sepsis: The patient is currently on levophed and vasopressin. Pressor weaning will be attempted today, along with fluid bolus and repeat until pressors can be weaned off. Strep Pneumonia is suspected, and antibiotics will be adjusted accordingly.
3. Renal Failure: Improved non-gap acidosis and urine output. Enhancing volume status will be done.
4. Altered Mental Status: CT reassuring, with some increased movement today. Minimizing sedation will be continued.
5. Shock: Remains pressor-dependent on vasopressin and levophed. Avoiding further volume resuscitation and maintaining mean arterial pressure (MAP) >55 with pressors will be the goal.
6. Hypernatremia (High Sodium): Ongoing assessment and management will be performed.

Please note that this summary is based on the provided information, and further evaluation by a healthcare professional is necessary for an accurate diagnosis and treatment plan.

   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of

   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure. He was transferred from another hospital and found to have GBS pneumonia and sepsis, as well as multiorgan failure (renal failure, respiratory failure, shock, acidosis). The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, sepsis, metabolic acidosis, renal failure, skin rash, altered mental status, anemia, hyponatremia, and a history of SVT and atrial fibrillation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has been treated for GBS pneumonia, but there are still barriers to extubation including altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis, bilateral pleural effusion, and improving pneumonia.

2. Sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his pneumonia. Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is less likely.

3. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient continues to have an anion gap, likely due to renal failure and lactic acidosis. Non-anion gap acidosis significantly improved.

4. Renal Failure: The patient has been diagnosed with acute tubular necrosis (ATN) from hypotension during sepsis. Supportive measures are being taken to maintain adequate blood pressure and fluid resuscitation.

   generalized pustulosis (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of
   psoriasis. derm path from [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction:
   consider drug-induced or viral etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome
   cannot be exluded. Less likely HSV [**Hospital1 5286**], but it it not completely
   impossible.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin [**Hospital1 5286**]
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Exam revealed some stereotypical decorticate
   reflexes. Unclear whether it is HSV encephalitis. Also likely [**12-21**]
   sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   - CT head x2 were negative for any intracranial process.
   - hold off on MRI for now
   - consider LP after clarification of goals of care
   - adequate blood pressure control for better perfusion of brain (goal
   MAP 65 but it may not be a realistic goal as the diastolic pressure has
   been very low). For now, maintain goal MAP at least 55 with IVF first,
   if still low then up the pressors. Hoping bicarb will help with
   acidosis and decrease pressor requirements and help with blood
   pressure.
   - continue thiamine
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 1u pRBC on [**8-13**]. On admission Hct was
   31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac positive, anemia of chronic
   disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR infiltrate. Fe studies revealed
   anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate are normal. No
   evidence of hemolysis or DIC at this point. Patient also has renal
   failure which also contributes to his anemia.
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct 21. Transfuse if hct <21
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h which was discontinued
   - continue to monitor
   #) SVT: didn
t have another episode during the past 48 hours. pt was
   found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT. Pt was hemodynamically
   unstable, SBP in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. In terms of
   etiologies of SVT, it is likely secondary to infection, volume
   depletion and levophed which is a beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - now that levophed restarted, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: now resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family
   - will need to watch this weekend, and see if he improves
   - will need to discuss tracheostomy early next week, patient will have
   been intubated for 2 weeks on Monday
   ICU Care

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure. He has diffuse desquamating skin lesions, GBS pneumonia, sepsis, and multiorgan failure (renal failure, respiratory failure, shock, acidosis). The patient is intubated and sedated, with altered mental status. He has been treated with penicillin G, clindamycin, and acyclovir. The patient's respiratory failure may be secondary to generalized HSV infection, and the current barriers to extubation include altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis, bilateral pleural effusion, and pneumonia which is improving. The patient also has renal failure, metabolic acidosis, anemia, hyponatremia, SVT, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, transaminitis, and hypothyroidism. The patient's goals of care are being discussed with the family.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is due to GBS pneumonia and possible generalized HSV infection. The current barriers to extubation include altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis, bilateral pleural effusion, and pneumonia which is improving.
2. Sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his pneumonia. Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is less likely.
3. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient continues to have an anion gap, likely

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer treatment. He was admitted to the hospital due to a diffuse rash and subsequently developed acute hypoxic respiratory failure, leading to intubation and transfer to the ICU.

The patient has been diagnosed with GBS pneumonia and HSV infection. His current condition is characterized by persistent respiratory failure, shock, metabolic acidosis (AG acidosis), and altered mental status (AMS). The patient's medical history also includes thrombocytopenia, impaired skin integrity, hypernatremia, renal failure, and supra ventricular tachycardia.

The potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Acute respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory system is severely compromised, which puts him at risk of further deterioration in oxygenation and ventilation. This may require continuous monitoring and intervention, such as adjustments in ventilator settings or consideration for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).

2. Shock: The patient is experiencing septic shock, which is a life-threatening condition characterized by inadequate blood flow to vital organs. Close monitoring of hemodynamic parameters and timely administration of appropriate fluids and vasopressors are crucial in managing this complication.

3. Metabolic acidosis (AG acidosis): The patient's blood pH is low, indicating metabolic acidosis. This condition can be caused by various factors, including inadequate oxygenation, sepsis, or renal dysfunction

Based on the provided information, the patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who has been hospitalized at OSH for a probable drug rash. He developed acute respiratory failure and sepsis, prompting his transfer to the ICU.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

1. Acute respiratory failure: The patient remains on mechanical ventilation to support his breathing, with adequate oxygenation but requiring a high respiratory rate to ventilate.

2. Shock: The patient continues to require vasopressor support to maintain his blood pressure.

3. Acidosis: The patient has metabolic acidosis, which was temporarily treated with bicarbonate infusion.

4. Altered mental status (AMS): The patient's mental status has been altered, possibly due to sedative medications. However, he is now off sedatives for 4-5 days with little change.

5. Acute renal failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, likely due to hypotension and acute tubular necrosis. Renal function is slowly improving, and nephrotoxins should be avoided.

6. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit level has decreased to 21%, indicating anemia. It is recommended to transfuse one unit of blood.

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was transferred to the ICU for respiratory failure. He has been diagnosed with GBS pneumonia and sepsis, as well as multiorgan failure (renal failure, respiratory failure, shock, acidosis). The patient's current medical complications include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has GBS pneumonia, which is being treated with penicillin G and clindamycin. However, the pneumonia appears to be worsening again, and there is a possibility of a generalized HSV infection. The current barriers to extubation include altered mental status, severe metabolic acidosis, infection, and hemodynamic instability.

2. Sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his pneumonia. Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but less likely. The patient continues on pressors (vasopressin and norepinephrine) to maintain blood pressure, and blood cultures have been negative.

3. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient continues to have acidosis, more non-gap in nature. Bicarb was previously given but has been discontinued due to increasing sodium intake and volume.

4. Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels have slowly improved, suggesting possible acute tubular necrosis (ATN) from hypotension during sepsis. Supportive measures include aggressive fluid resuscitation with lactated Ringer's solution (LR) and renal dosing

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating skin, GBS pneumonia, sepsis, and multiorgan failure (renal failure/resp failure/shock/acidosis). He has been treated with penicillin G and clindamycin for GBS pneumonia, acyclovir for HSV infection, and doxycycline for possible tick-borne illness. The patient continues to have metabolic acidosis, altered mental status, anemia, hyponatremia, SVT, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, transaminitis, and hypothyroidism.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has GBS pneumonia, which is being treated with penicillin G and clindamycin. The worsening of pneumonia on imaging indicates a potential complication.
2. Infection: The patient has sepsis and multiorgan failure, suggesting a systemic infection. The source of infection is likely pulmonary due to GBS pneumonia. There is also a possibility of generalized HSV infection.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient continues to have non-gap metabolic acidosis. The cause may be sepsis, renal failure, or other factors.
4. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status could be due to HSV encephalitis, prolonged sepsis, or sedation.
5. Renal

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer, currently admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating rash, GBS pneumonia, sepsis, multiorgan failure (renal failure/resp failure/shock/acidosis), and HSV infection. The patient is pressor-dependent on vasopressin and levophed, with ongoing pleural effusions and normal CVP. The patient's mental status is altered, and there is evidence of digital ischemia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has been treated for GBS pneumonia, but still has bilateral pleural effusion and pneumonia which is improving. There is a risk of ongoing respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's source of infection is likely pulmonary given his pneumonia. Generalized HSV infection is another possibility. The patient remains pressor-dependent, indicating ongoing sepsis.
3. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient continues to have an anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely due to renal failure and lactic acidosis.
4. Renal Failure: The patient has an improving creatinine level, indicating possible recovery from renal failure. However, the patient is still on renal replacement therapy and requires careful fluid management.
5. Altered Mental Status: The patient has altered mental status, which may be due to HSV encephalitis, sedation, or prolonged sepsis. Further evaluation is needed, including a CT head

   found to have GBS pneumonia and sepsis and multiorgan failure (renal

   imaging last week but worsening again.  Possibly has component of
   generalized HSV infection-- HSV DFA and culture from mini-BAL are
   pending. The current barriers to extubation include altered mental
   status, severe metabolic acidosis, infection, hemodynamic instability.
   TTE showed normal EF, r/o CHF. Patient's smoking history puts him at
   risk for COPD.  Pt has HSV infection from two sources (nasopharynx and
   lip).
   - on  AC currently, has increased work of breathing; Rule out autopeep
   - trial of Pressure Support in order to decrease his work of breathing
   - continue day 11 of penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (for
   GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]),
   - continue clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day1: [**8-6**]) to inhibit
   toxin production
   - continue day 13 of acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per
   ID this presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - continue day 9 of doxy for possible tick borne illness (day1: [**8-8**]);
   if RMSF Neg,  will d/c doxy
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   - intubated x2 wks
 discuss Goals of Care for tomorrow
   .
   #) Sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his
   pneumonia.   Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is
   less likely.  [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim was normal.  Continues on pressors--
   vasopressin and norepinephrine.  UA was negative. Blood culture has
   been negative, and TTE on [**8-3**] showed no vegetation. No evidence of
   sinusitis, so no need for CT sinus at this time.  Consider Toxic Shock
   Syndrome, given desquamating [**Month/Year (2) 5286**]
   - continue pressors, but titrate pressors to Urine output >30ccs/hr,
   independent of MAP; continue to monitor MAP
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel: f/u on RMSF, Anaplasma
   phagocytophilum (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Babesia
   Antibodies, IgG and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster
   Antibody, IgM
   - because of pleural effusions and normal CVP, electing to maintain MAP
   with pressors rather than IVF
   .

   more non-gap.  Was given bicarb previously, but bicarb is increasing
   his sodium intake, which is increasing his volume
   - d/c bicarb
   - give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .

   hypotension from sepsis.
   - support blood pressure for adequate perfusion of kidneys
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin [**Last Name (LF) 5286**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   aggressively resuscitate with LR
   - renally dose medications
   .

   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome.  Has new hemorrhagic bulla on hand, possibly

d due to possibility of drug [**First Name3 (LF) 5286**] being the etiology
   of skin process.  Per derm, this is either GBS, generalized pustulosis
   (benign drug reaction) or perhaps flare of psoriasis. derm path from
   [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity reaction: consider drug-induced or viral
   etiology.  Paraneoplastic syndrome cannot be exluded. Less likely HSV
   [**Hospital1 5286**], but it it not completely impossible.
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin [**Hospital1 5286**]
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Had some stereotypical decorticate reflexes
   yesterday. Possibility of HSV encephalitis. Also likely [**12-21**] sedation
   and prolonged sepsis.
   - CT head x2 were negative for any intracranial process.
   - hold off on MRI for now
   - consider LP after clarification of goals of care
   - adequate blood pressure control for better perfusion of brain, but
   will titrate pressors to urine output >30ccs/hr.
   - continue thiamine
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, received 1u pRBC on [**8-13**] and 1 unit pRBCs [**8-15**].
   On admission Hct was 31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was guaiac
   positive, anemia of chronic disease / inflammation or DAH given CXR
   infiltrate. Fe studies revealed anemia of chronic disease/inflammation.
   B12 and folate are normal. Patient also has renal failure which also
   contributes to his anemia.
   - repeat coags and get DIC labs
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor, goal Hct 21. Transfuse if hct <21

   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h which was discontinued.  Hyponatremia 133 from
   yesterday improved to 137 yesterday evening and 136 this morning.
   -continue to monitor
   #) SVT:  pt was found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT with no
   recent episodes in last 3 days.  Pt was hemodynamically unstable, SBP
   in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. Differential for etiology
   of SVT includes infection, volume depletion and levophed which is a
   beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - in setting of levophed restart, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unsure
   if he really has hypothyrodism or sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not
   check thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - family meeting tomorrow today
   - pt intubated x 2 weeks -- will need to discuss tracheostomy option
   with family in addition to goals of care and possible withdrawal of
   care

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating skin lesions, GBS pneumonia, and sepsis. The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, sepsis, multiorgan failure (renal failure/resp failure/shock/acidosis), HSV infection, altered mental status, metabolic acidosis, renal failure, and anemia. The patient has undergone various interventions and treatments, including antibiotics, antiviral medication, and pressors to maintain blood pressure.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Prolonged intubation: The patient has been intubated for two weeks and may require a tracheostomy to facilitate weaning off mechanical ventilation.

2. Infection: The patient is at risk for developing new infections due to prolonged immobility, use of indwelling lines, and immunosuppression from sepsis and medications.

3. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and further deterioration can lead to the need for dialysis.

4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient continues to have acidosis, which needs to be closely monitored and managed.

5. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is altered, and there is a possibility of HSV encephalitis. Further evaluation, such as a lumbar puncture, may be necessary.

6. Anemia: The patient has anemia, and

 discuss Goals of Care for tomorrow

   #) Sepsis: The source of infection is likely pulmonary given his
   pneumonia.   Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is

   vasopressin and norepinephrine.  UA was negative. Blood culture has

   - continue pressors, but titrate pressors to Urine output >30ccs/hr,
   independent of MAP; continue to monitor MAP
   - treat underlying PNA.  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8

   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection

   Assessment and Plan
   84 year old male with h/o throat cancer who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **] to [**Hospital1 1**] with respiratory failure, diffuse desquamating [**Hospital1 5286**],
   found to have GBS pneumonia and sepsis and multiorgan failure (renal
   failure/resp failure/shock/acidosis).
   #) Respiratory failure:   Has GBS pneumonia, being treated with
   penicillin G and clindamycin.  Clinical improvement questionable.
   Possibly has component of generalized HSV infection.  The current
   barriers to extubation include altered mental status, infection,
   hemodynamic instability.  TTE showed normal EF, r/o CHF. Patient's
   smoking history puts him at risk for COPD.
   - on  AC, no longer appears to have increased work of breathing
   - continue day 12 of penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8 hours (for
   GBS) (day1: [**8-6**]),
   - continue clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours (day1: [**8-6**]) to inhibit
   toxin production
   - continue day 14 of acyclovir for HSV infection (day1: [**8-4**]), as per
   ID this presentation could represent HSV generalized infection
   - Doxy D/Ced yesterday b/c RMSF negative and had completed full 8 day
   course regardless for RMSF
   - f/u remaining cultures
   - f/u on ID recs
   - intubated x2 wks
 discuss Goals of Care at family meeting this
   afternoon
   .
   #) Sepsis/ Hypotension:  Secondary to GBS pneumonia and possible Toxic
   Shock Syndrome.   Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but
   is less likely.  [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim was normal.   Has been recently on pressors
   vasopressin and norepinephrine, but was able to titrate off levophed
   late this morning.
   - continue vasopressin as needed, but titrate pressors to Urine output
   >30ccs/hr, independent of MAP; continue to monitor MAP
   - treat underlying PNA--  continue penicillin G 4 million units IV q 8
   hours (for GBS), clindamycin 900 mg IV q 8 hours to inhibit toxin
   production
   - continue acyclovir for HSV infection
   - f/u cultures and other infectious panel:    Anaplasma phagocytophilum
   (human granulocytic Ehrlichia [**Doctor Last Name 23**]) IgG/IgM; Babesia Antibodies, IgG
   and IgM; Parvovirus B19 Antibodies; Varicella zoster Antibody, IgM
   .
   #) [**Doctor Last Name **]: OSH biopsy diagnosed leukoclastic vasculitis, however, given
   pt was GBS positive in sputum culture, question whether it is related
   to toxic shock syndrome.  Has new hemorrhagic bulla on hand, possibly
   indicating progression of the desquamating skin process.  Per derm,
   cefepime was d/c
d due to possibility of drug [**Doctor Last Name 5286**] being the etiology
   of skin process.  Derm path from [**Hospital1 **]: c/w hypersensitivity
   reaction: consider drug-induced or viral etiology.   Paraneoplastic
   syndrome cannot be exluded. Much less likely HSV [**Hospital1 5286**].
   - on clindamycin to inhibit toxin production
   - continue acyclovir per ID
   - continue triamcinolone ointment [**Hospital1 **] for skin [**Hospital1 5286**]
   - continue Aquafor [**Hospital1 **]
    -wound care (pt also has ulcer on coccyx)
   - f/u any new derm recs
   - no advil/motrin
   .
   #) Altered mental status: Unclear baseline mental status. Has corneal
   and pupilary reflexes and responds to painful stimuli.  [**Month (only) 11**] have
   cerebral edema.  Possibility of HSV encephalitis. Also may be secondary
   to sedation and prolonged sepsis.
   - CT head x2 were negative for any intracranial process.
   - consider LP after clarification of goals of care
   - adequate blood pressure control for better perfusion of brain at this
   time -- titrating pressors to urine output >30ccs/hr.
   - continue thiamine
   .
   #) Metabolic acidosis:  pt continues to have acidosis, but appears to
   be more non-gap.
   - if patient were to need fluids, give LR instead of NS if giving IVF
   .
   #) Renal Failure:  Cr slowly improving.   Most likely secondary to ATN
   from hypotension from sepsis.
   - support blood pressure for adequate perfusion of kidneys
   - as pt has lots of insensible fluid loss from skin [**Last Name (LF) 5286**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   aggressively resuscitate with LR as needed
   - renally dose medications
   .
   #) Anemia: Hct 20.1 today . Had received 1u pRBC on [**8-13**] and 1 unit
   pRBCs [**8-15**]. On admission Hct was 31.4. DDx includes GIB given he was
   guaiac positive, anemia of chronic disease.  Does not likely have DAH,
   though it is still on differential in setting of CXR infiltrate. Fe
   studies revealed anemia of chronic disease/inflammation. B12 and folate
   are normal. Patient also has renal failure which also contributes to
   his anemia.  Repeat coags and DIC Labs normal except for elevated
   D-dimer which is very non-specific.
   - Hold on transfusion of 1u pRBCs until after family meeting to discuss
   goals of care
   - guaiac all stools
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #) Hyponatremia: Patient initially had hypernatremia up to 150, s/p
   free water flushes q6h which was discontinued.  Hyponatremia 133 from
   two days ago improved to 136 yesterday and 142 today.
   -continue to monitor
   #) SVT:  pt was found to be in SVT, most likely AVNRT or AVNT with no
   recent episodes in last 3 days.  Pt was hemodynamically unstable, SBP
   in the 70s to 80s despite being on levophed. Differential for etiology
   of SVT includes infection, volume depletion and levophed which is a
   beta1 agonist.
   - per family, cardiovert if pt goes back into SVT with hemodynamic
   instability
   - in setting of levophed restart, need to monitor
   .
   #) Afib with RVR: resolved. was in SVT (AVRT or AVNRT), s/p
   cardioversion
   - continue to monitor on tele
   .
   #) Transaminitis: Resolved, liver synthetic function good.
   .
   #) Hypothyroidism: pt was started on levothyroxine at OSH, but unclear
   if actual hypothyrodism vs. sick euthyroid syndrome. Would not check
   thyroid function at this time as pt is acutely ill in ICU.
   - levothyroxine was discontinued in the setting of SVT
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - family meeting today
   - pt intubated x 2 weeks -- will need to discuss tracheostomy option
   with family in addition to goals of care and possible withdrawal of
   care

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 84-year-old male with a history of throat cancer who was admitted to the ICU due to respiratory failure. He has been diagnosed with GBS pneumonia, sepsis, and multiorgan failure (renal failure/resp failure/shock/acidosis). The patient's current barriers to extubation include altered mental status, infection, and hemodynamic instability. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1) Respiratory failure: The patient has GBS pneumonia, being treated with penicillin G and clindamycin. Clinical improvement is questionable, possibly due to generalized HSV infection. The current barriers to extubation include altered mental status, infection, and hemodynamic instability.
2) Sepsis/hypotension: Secondary to GBS pneumonia and possible Toxic Shock Syndrome. Generalized HSV infection is another possibility but is less likely.
3) Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, indicating renal failure. This may be secondary to ATN from hypotension due to sepsis.
4) Metabolic acidosis: The patient continues to have acidosis, which appears to be non-gap. If the patient were to need fluids, it is recommended to give LR instead of NS.
5) Altered mental status: Unclear baseline mental status. The patient has corneal and pupilary reflexes and responds to painful stimuli. Possibility of HSV encephalitis. Also may be secondary to sedation and
